impression:

impression:
PA and lateral chest reviewed in the absence of prior chest
 imaging:
 
 Moderate bilateral pleural effusions layer dependently.  Cardiac silhouette
 has a peculiar shape, and a larger than expected component to the right of
 midline.  Whether this is due to cardiomegaly or pericardial effusion is
 indeterminate.  There is no particular distention of either pulmonary or

 Dr. ___ was paged.
summarized: CXR: Moderate bilateral pleural effusions and mild bibasilar atelectasis; no pulmonary edema. Abnormal rightward cardiac silhouette—cardiomegaly vs pericardial effusion indeterminate. Aorta normal.

impression:

impression:

summarized: Pacemaker leads in RA/RV. Stable heart/mediastinum. Basal interstitial opacities unchanged, favor ILD with possible fibrosis; infection unlikely. Recommend chest CT. No effusion or pneumothorax.

impression:

impression:

impression:

impression:

 wedge resection of the right middle lobe lesion.
 
 Assessment of the thoracic spine is suspicious for DISH.
 
 Overall no new findings demonstrated and abnormalities that would explain

impression:

 3.  Pigtail catheter posterior along the posterior base of the chest; its

impression:

impression:

 pneumonia given clinical suspicion for pneumonia.  However, recurrent
 malignancy is an additional consideration, particularly considering adjacent
 persistent enlargement and increased density of the right hilum.  
 
 Management recommendation for this finding is treatment for pneumonia with

 potential clinical concern for aortic dissection, an immediate chest CTA

summarized: New R juxtahilar opacity: likely early pneumonia; possible recurrence with enlarged/dense R hilum. Treat pneumonia; short-term CXR f/u. If aortic dissection concern, urgent chest CTA; CXR insensitive

 chest radiographs:
 
 Solitary calcified granuloma is present at the right lung apex.  There is
 minimal scarring in the lingula, but no findings suggesting reactivation
 tuberculosis.  Hyperinflation and flattening of the diaphragm contours
 indicate emphysema or small airway obstruction.  Heart is normal size.  Hilar
 and mediastinal contours are unremarkable.
summarized: Chest X-ray: R apical calcified granuloma; minimal lingular scarring; no TB reactivation. Hyperinflation/flat diaphragms suggest emphysema or small airway obstruction. Heart, hila, mediastinum normal.

impression:
PA and lateral chest reviewed in the absence of prior chest
 radiographs:
 
 Mild interstitial pulmonary abnormality is reflected in bronchial cuffing and
 fissural thickening.  There is also a small volume of pleural fluid in each
 hemithorax.  The heart is normal size.  Pulmonary vasculature and mediastinal
 veins are not distended.  I suppose the interstitial abnormality could be
 infectious, but the symmetry and dependent distribution argue for edema, but
 there are no concurrent cardiovascular findings.  Does the patient have low
 serum albumin or perhaps she recently got an intravascular volume load, but it
 is no longer hypervolemic.
 
 After her lungs clear, she should have a repeat chest radiograph because of
 the possibility of an 8-mm wide nodule in the left lung projecting over the
 fifth anterior interspace.
summarized: CXR: Mild interstitial changes with small bilat pleural effusions; heart normal; no vascular distention. Edema > infection. Repeat CXR after clearing for poss 8 mm L lung nodule.

impression:
In comparison with the study of ___, the patient has taken a better
 inspiration.  The cardiac silhouette is within upper limits of normal and
 there is again mild tortuosity of the aorta.  Mild atelectatic changes are
 seen at the left base, but no evidence of vascular congestion, pleural
 effusion, or acute focal pneumonia.
 The left IJ Port-A-Cath extends to the mid to lower portion of the SVC.
summarized: Improved inspiration vs prior. Cardiac silhouette upper normal; mild aortic tortuosity. Mild left basilar atelectasis. No congestion, effusion, or pneumonia. Left IJ Port-A-Cath to mid-lower SVC.

impression:
In comparison with the study of ___, there are lower lung volumes. 
 This probably accounts for the increased prominence of the transverse diameter
 of the heart.  Retrocardiac opacification most likely represents atelectatic
 changes.  However, in the appropriate clinical setting, the possibility of a
 superimposed pneumonia would have to be considered.
 No evidence of vascular congestion.  Central catheter extends to the mid to
 lower portion of the SVC.
summarized: Compared to prior, lung volumes are lower, likely making heart appear larger. Retrocardiac opacity favors atelectasis; pneumonia not excluded. No vascular congestion. Central line to mid-lower SVC.

impression:
There is minimal blunting of left costophrenic angle and patchy opacity at the
 left base which may reflect a combination of atelectasis and or scarring in
 the setting of a small effusion or chronic pleural thickening.  An early
 infectious process should also be considered.  Clinical correlation is
 recommended.  No pulmonary edema or pneumothorax.  Overall cardiac and
 mediastinal contours are within normal limits.
summarized: Minimal L costophrenic blunting and L base opacity; c/w atelectasis/scar with small effusion or chronic pleural thickening; early infection possible. No edema/pneumothorax. Cardiomediastinum normal.

impression:

 lower lobe.  The other described left basilar opacity is no longer apparent. 
 There is minimal blunting of the left costophrenic angle which could reflect a
 tiny effusion.  The right lung is grossly clear.  Overall, cardiac and
 mediastinal contours are stable.  No evidence of pulmonary edema or
 pneumothorax.
summarized: Likely pneumonia in superior segment of LLL; prior left basilar opacity resolved. Possible tiny left pleural effusion. Right lung clear. Cardiomediastinal contours stable. No edema or pneumothorax.

impression:

impression:
PA and lateral chest compared to baseline chest radiograph
 ___ and ___:
 
 Emphysema and scarring are so severe that it is difficult to say whether
 pneumothorax is entirely resolved.  The walls of giant bullae mimic a pleural
 edge, and it is possible that adhesions developing in the pleural space could,
 in turn mimic the walls of bullae.  My best judgment, however, is that there
 is no appreciable residual pneumothorax.  If there were, there would be a
 fluid level with respect to the small right pleural effusion.  The fluid level
 one can see on the current lateral view is in the stomach.
 
 Spontaneous pneumothorax even in patients with severe emphysema is relatively
 rare and raises concern for predisposing conditions such as a subpleural
 malignancy.  At some point, it would be prudent to perform a chest CT looking
 for malignancy, and it might be necessary to do a chest CT to exclude
 pneumothorax.
summarized: Severe emphysema/scarring with giant bullae. No apparent residual pneumothorax; small R pleural effusion. Lateral fluid level is gastric. Recommend chest CT to assess malignancy, exclude PTX.

impression:
There is indeed moderate right pneumothorax, despite the right pigtail pleural
 drainage catheter.  Lateral view is recommended to exclude fissural placement
 of the catheter.  Patient has extremely severe bullous emphysema.  Radiographs
 earlier in this illness should be evaluated to see if pneumothorax preceded
 placement of the drain.
 
 The generalized increase in left perihilar interstitial abnormality could be
 due to redirection of blood flow contributing to borderline edema.  Right
 pleural effusion is minimal.  Heart size is normal.
summarized: Moderate R PTX despite R pigtail drain; lateral view to exclude fissural cath. Severe bullous emphysema. Increased L perihilar interstitial changes/borderline edema. Minimal R effusion. Heart normal.

 interstitial pulmonary abnormality with septal lines at the right lung base
 laterally and mild bronchial cuffing.  Hila are not enlarged, but the right
 paratracheal stripe is partially obliterated, raising question of central
 lymph node enlargement.  Heart size is normal.
 
 Lateral view shows small bilateral pleural effusion and thickening of the
 posterior wall of the bronchus intermedius which may be due to either edema or
 lymph node enlargement.
 
 There is no way to know given the patient's history of intravenous drug use,

 infection, particularly virus.
 
 A ___-mm wide nodular opacity projects over the right sixth anterior interspace

impression:
Hyper expansion and distorted vascular branching indicate emphysema. Small
 bilateral pleural effusion new since ___ is slightly larger today
 than on ___. Sometimes the development of pleural effusion and it and
 minimal interstitial abnormality are the only manifestations of congestive
 heart failure in patients with severe COPD. There is no pneumonia.
 
 Left jugular line ends in the SVC.  No pneumothorax.
summarized: Findings of emphysema. Small bilateral pleural effusions, new and slightly increased vs prior; may reflect CHF in severe COPD. No pneumonia. Left IJ line in SVC. No pneumothorax.

impression:
Compared to chest radiographs ___.
 
 Emphysema is moderate to severe.  Since ___, pleural effusions, moderate on
 the left stable, small on the right decreased.  Left infrahilar consolidation
 could be residual atelectasis, more pronounced previously.  There is no
 pulmonary edema.  Multiple lung nodules are more obvious.  Heart size is
 normal.  No pneumothorax.  Left jugular central venous infusion catheter ends
 in the mid SVC.
summarized: Mod–severe emphysema. Effusions: L mod stable; R small ↓. L infrahilar consolidation c/w residual atelectasis (prev worse). No edema/PTX; heart size nl. Mult nodules more obvious. L IJ CVC tip mid-SVC.

impression:
In comparison with the study of ___, the tip of the Port-A-Cath is in the
 upper to mid SVC.  Again there is hyperexpansion of the lungs with flattening
 hemidiaphragms consistent with chronic pulmonary disease.  No acute focal
 pneumonia, vascular congestion, or pleural effusion.
 There is vague suggestion of some nodular opacifications at the bases,
 especially on the right, which was seen to much better advantage on a prior CT
 scan.
summarized: Port-A-Cath tip in upper-mid SVC. Hyperinflated lungs, flattened diaphragms c/w chronic lung disease. No pneumonia, vascular congestion, or effusion. Basilar nodules, esp R; better seen on prior CT.

impression:
PA and lateral chest compared to ___ and ___:
 
 Moderate right pleural effusion is larger.  Severe cardiomegaly is probably
 larger as well and pulmonary vascular engorgement is essentially unchanged. 
 Dual-channel right supraclavicular central venous dialysis catheter ends in
 the low SVC and right atrium.  Right jugular line ends in the upper right
 atrium.  Opacification of the left lower lobe which developed between ___
 and ___ is either atelectasis or pneumonia but has not changed subsequently. 
 There is no appreciable left pleural effusion.
summarized: Moderate R pleural effusion ↑. Severe cardiomegaly prob ↑; PV engorgement unchanged. R supraclav dialysis cath in low SVC/RA; R IJ in upper RA. Stable LLL opacity (atelectasis vs PNA). No L effusion.

impression:
PA and lateral chest compared to ___:
 
 Moderate-sized hiatus hernia is larger.  There is no good evidence for
 pneumonia.  Small right pleural effusion is new and the pulmonary vasculature

impression:
Comparison to ___.  The patient has undergone video assisted left

summarized: Post left VATS: left pleural thickening and horizontal scar. No large left pleural effusion or left pneumothorax. Ventilation improved vs prior. Cardiac silhouette normal unchanged.

impression:
Interval resolution of the left lower lobe pneumonia.
 
 Previously seen opacity at the level of the right fifth anterior rib  is no
 longer seen on the current study.
 
 Previously seen opacity at the level of the left fifth anterior rib persists. 
 Repeat chest x-ray is recommended in 2 months for evaluation.  If the opacity
 still persists, then CT is recommended for further characterization.
summarized: Left lower lobe pneumonia resolved. Right 5th anterior rib opacity resolved; left 5th persists. Repeat chest X-ray in 2 months; if persistent, proceed to CT.

impression:

impression:

 opacity at the right medial lung base which most likely reflects atelectasis,

 seen on the chest CT dated ___ are not well visualized on plain

 Left subclavian Port-A-Cath unchanged in position.  No pneumothorax.

impression:

impression:

 At the resolution limits of plain radiography, no definite pulmonary or

impression:
1.  There has been interval decrease in lung volumes.  There is a small right
 layering pleural effusion which in retrospect was present on the CT study of
 ___.  Vague patchy opacity is seen in the right costophrenic angle,
 which may represent an infectious or inflammatory process given the interval

 opacity in the right hilar area which likely corresponds to the

summarized: Decreased lung volumes. Small R pleural effusion. Patchy R costophrenic opacity c/w infection/inflammation. R hilar LAD. No consolidation, PTX, or edema. Breast CA mets; atypical infection possible.

impression:

 Severe hyperinflation is chronic.  There are no focal pulmonary abnormalities.
 Mild eventration of the left hemidiaphragm posteriorly is also chronic.  Heart
 size is normal.  Pulmonary vasculature and pleural surfaces are normal.
 
 A slight increase in the attenuation of obliquely oriented tissue crossing the
 medial right clavicle could be due to greater prominence of the head and neck

 CT scanning to exclude a subtle lung mass.
 
 Heart size is normal.  Thoracic aorta is prominent only because of the

impression:
Overall, given differences in positioning, there is no significant interval
 change of near complete opacification of the left hemi-thorax, although there
 is some aeration in the left upper lung.  This likely reflects a combination
 of consolidation/atelectasis and to a lesser degree, pleural fluid, especially
 when correlated with CT dated ___.  The mass in the right upper lobe is
 again seen and consistent with primary lung malignancy when correlated with CT
 ___ ___.  Patchy opacities at the right lung base more likely reflect
 areas of atelectasis rather than superimposed pneumonia.  Interval removal of
 bibasilar pigtail pleural catheters.  No pneumothorax.  Cardiac and
 mediastinal contours are difficult to assess due to the opacification of the
 left hemi-thorax.
summarized: No interval change. Near-complete left hemithorax opacification; slight LUL aeration. Likely consolidation/atelectasis > effusion. RUL mass c/w lung cancer. R base atelectasis. Pigtails out. No PTX.

impression:
1.  There is no pneumothorax after left lower lung biopsy.  Increased density
 in left lower lung is due to hemorrhage after procedure.
 2.  Bilateral widespread interstitial and ground-glass opacities are under
 investigation, slightly increased since ___.  The first diagnosis
 to consider would be an infectious process, primarily pneumocystis infection
 in an HIV patient. Considering the cysts and the nodules on recent CT scan,
 LIP could also be considered.
summarized: Post-LLL biopsy: no pneumothorax; increased density from hemorrhage. Bilateral interstitial/ground-glass opacities mildly increased. Likely infection (PCP in HIV); LIP possible with cysts/nodules.

impression:
The right subclavian PICC line continues to have its tip in the mid to distal
 SVC. Overall cardiac and mediastinal contours are likely unchanged. Streaky
 opacities at both bases may reflect atelectasis or scarring, less likely
 superimposed infection. Clinical correlation is advised. No evidence of
 pulmonary edema or pneumothorax.  No free intraperitoneal air.  No large
 effusions. Subtle deformity of the right posterior lateral eighth rib likely
 reflecting old trauma.  No acute bony abnormality appreciated.
summarized: R subclavian PICC tip mid–distal SVC. CM stable. Bilat basilar streaks c/w atelectasis/scar; infxn less likely. No edema, PTX large effusions, pneumoperitoneum. R 8th rib old deformity; no acute fx.

impression:
1. No evidence of acute cardiopulmonary process.
 
 2. Stable appearance of linear opacities involving the right mid lung zone,
 which likely represents scarring and postoperative changes related to right
 lower lobe wedge resection.  
 
 3. Ill-defined opacity projecting over ascending aorta is more conspicuous
 from ___ exam and may represent enlarging pulmonary nodule.
summarized: No acute cardiopulmonary process. Stable R mid-lung scarring/postop change likely from RLL wedge resection. More conspicuous ill-defined opacity over asc aorta; possible enlarging pulmonary nodule.

impression:
As compared to the previous radiograph, the lung volumes have improved, likely
 reflecting improved ventilation. Unchanged right-sided healed rib fracture. 
 Unchanged small hiatal hernia. The air in the soft tissues of the chest wall
 has completely resolved. The sternal wires show normal alignment. Mild
 cardiomegaly but no pulmonary edema.  No evidence of pathologic parenchymal
 opacities.  No evidence of pleural effusions on the frontal and lateral chest
 x-ray.
summarized: Improved lung volumes. Unchanged healed right rib fracture and small hiatal hernia. Resolved chest wall air. Sternal wires aligned. Mild cardiomegaly without edema. No opacities or effusions.

impression:

 Severe elevation of the left hemidiaphragm which worsened between ___ and

 Lungs are clear.  Heart is slightly larger exaggerated by generally lower lung

summarized: Stable severe left hemidiaphragm elevation; phrenic palsy vs eventration unclear. Lungs clear. Mild cardiomegaly exaggerated by low volumes. No vascular engorgement, edema, or effusion.

impression:
1.  Interval near complete resolution of pulmonary edema with residual chronic

 2.  Decreased right medial lung base and left mid-to-lower lung heterogeneous

 3.  Increased left retrocardiac atelectasis.

summarized: Pulm edema near-resolved; residual interstitial changes likely from LCH. ↓ R medial base/L mid-lower opacities (possible infxn). ↑ left retrocardiac atelectasis. Stable small-mod b/l pleural effusions

impression:
As compared to the previous radiograph, the right-sided effusion has minimally

 lateral image.  The subsequent areas of atelectasis at the right lung bases

 Overall, the lung volumes remain low. The size of the cardiac silhouette is

summarized: vs prior: right pleural effusion slightly increased (frontal and lateral). Right basilar atelectasis unchanged. No new parenchymal opacities. Low lung volumes. Cardiac silhouette unchanged.

impression:
Status post pleural biopsy, status post talc pleurodesis.  The right

 Unchanged appearance of the left lung and of the left heart border. No

summarized: Right pleural effusion increased; intrafissural component and layering. Mild right vascular enlargement. Left lung/heart border unchanged. No pneumothorax. Stable right mediastinal/hilar densities.

impression:

summarized: Since prior: central lines removed. Right mediastinal lesions and interstitial changes progressed. 3 cm right lateral lung nodule better seen. Right pleural effusion stable. Left lung normal.

impression:
Compared to chest radiographs since ___, most recently ___.
 
 Lungs are mildly hyperinflated, and clear.  Previous mild pulmonary edema has
 resolved moderate cardiomegaly is chronic.  Left trans subclavian right atrial
 pacer and right ventricular pacer leads follow their expected courses from the

summarized: CXR: Mild hyperinflation; lungs clear. Prior mild edema resolved. Chronic moderate cardiomegaly. Left subclavian RA/RV pacer leads in expected course; LV distal lead circuitous—assessment advised.

impression:
As compared to the previous radiograph, a hemodialysis catheter was inserted

impression:
Compared to chest radiographs since ___ most recent ___,

 Lung volumes are essentially normal, unchanged and there is no lobar collapse

 Heart size is size is top-normal.

impression:
1. Overall little interval change in the appearance of the chest compared to
 the recent radiographic exam.
 2. Persistent left upper lobe rounded opacity a reflective of radiation
 fibrosis with probable recurrent tumor.
 3. Continued left perihilar opacity compatible with malignancy.
 4. Persistent interstitial opacities within the lung bases may reflect mild
 pulmonary edema but lymphangitic carcinomatosis remains in the differential.
 5. Small to moderate partially loculated left pleural effusion and trace right
 pleural effusions, unchanged with left basilar chest tube in place.
 6. Retrocardiac opacity may reflect atelectasis but infection is not excluded.
summarized: Minimal change. LUL post-RT fibrosis; probable recur. L hilar CA. Basal interst.: edema vs lymphangitic CA. Sm-mod loc L pl eff; trace R; L chest tube. Retrocard. atelectasis vs infection.

impression:
PA and lateral chest compared to ___:

summarized: RUL atelectasis worse vs prior; fiducials from local RT. Chronic moderate cardiomegaly. Small longstanding bilateral effusions. Severe MAC with PV engorgement, no edema. Lower lungs clear.

impression:

impression:

 pulmonary process.

 9:30am on ___, at the time of attending review.

impression:

 generalized increase in interstitial structures is unchanged as compared to
 the previous image, there is a history of known interstitial lung disease. The
 lung volumes are low. Moderate cardiomegaly with elongation of the descending

impression:
Diffuse bilateral interstitial opacities, very likely secondary to increased
 pulmonary edema from congestive heart failure, on a background of patient's
 known chronic interstitial lung disease.
 
 Short term follow up radiographs after diuresis is recommended to ensure
 resolution and to exclude other process such as atypical pneumonia or acute
 exacerbation of interstitial lung disease.
summarized: Diffuse bilateral interstitial opacities, likely CHF-related pulmonary edema on chronic ILD. Short-term post-diuresis CXR to ensure resolution and exclude atypical pneumonia or ILD exacerbation.

impression:

 appropriate, chest CT is suggested to evaluate further in followup.
 
 An email regarding the findings and recommendations was sent to the ED QA
 nursing group on ___.
summarized: No acute disease. New nodular focus at right lung apex, possible pulmonary nodule vs bone island/scar. Recommend chest CT for further evaluation when clinically appropriate.

impression:
In comparison with the study of ___, there is little overall change. 
 Enlargement of the hila and peritracheal region is again seen.  This is
 consistent with the CT combination of prominent mediastinal lymph nodes, which
 would be consistent with sarcoidosis, and substantial enlargement of the
 central pulmonary arteries, consistent with pulmonary arterial hypertension. 
 The cardiac silhouette remains enlarged, though there is no evidence of

 cardiomyopathy.
summarized: Minimal change. Hilar/peritracheal enlargement from mediastinal nodes (sarcoidosis). Enlarged central pulmonary arteries suggest PAH. Cardiomegaly without congestion; consider cardiomyopathy.

impression:
1.  Findings suggesting mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy, typical but not
 specific for sarcoidosis.  There is a lack of available remote prior studies. 
 Other etiologies such as lymphoma are not excluded.
 
 2.  Suggestion of mild congestive change with mild cardiomegaly.  The
 possibility of underlying cardiac disease should be considered. 
 Echocardiogram may be helpful to evaluate further.
 
 Regarding chest findings, CT may be useful to delineated further; if no prior
 studies are available, short-term follow-up radiographs are suggested.
summarized: Mediastinal/hilar LAD suggestive of sarcoidosis; lymphoma not excluded. Mild cardiomegaly/congestion; consider cardiac disease; echo advised. No priors. Chest CT & short-term f/u CXR advised.

impression:

impression:

 is probably mild pulmonary edema.

impression:

 pleural effusion, better appreciated on the lateral than on the frontal

summarized: New mild right pleural effusion (better seen on lateral). New right 6th rib lateral fracture. Lungs clear; no pneumonia. Cardiac size normal. No pulmonary edema or pneumothorax.

impression:

impression:
PA and lateral chest read in conjunction with chest CT, ___:

 upper lobe lesion on the ___ chest CT.  It is hard to say whether the

impression:

summarized: Stable cardiomegaly. Mild interstitial prominence. No consolidation, edema, or pneumothorax. Old left rib deformity; lower thoracic vertebroplasty. Tortuous aorta. No acute bony injury.

impression:

impression:

 Heart size normal.  No evidence of central adenopathy or pleural abnormality.

impression:
Compared to chest radiographs since ___, most recently ___.
 
 Bullous emphysema is extremely severe, with basal predominance raising
 possibility of panacinar emphysema due to alpha one antitrypsin deficiency. 
 There is a very small region of possible peribronchial opacification
 projecting over the lower pole of the left hilus on the frontal view, and over
 the descending thoracic aorta on the lateral.  This could be a very small
 pneumonia.  Oblique views would be helpful in evaluation.
 
 Blunting of the pleural sulci is due to inversion of the displaced diaphragm,
 not pleural effusion.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal.
summarized: Severe basal bullous emphysema; consider AATD panacinar. Tiny left peribronchial opacity—possible small pneumonia; obliques advised. Pleural sulci blunted from diaphragmatic inversion; no effusion.

impression:

impression:

 Although previously attributed to round atelectasis, its  growth and margins

 These findings were discussed with Dr. ___ via phone at 3:05 p.m.

impression:

summarized: Peripheral, asymmetric reticular opacities, worse in left lung, have increased, suggesting worsening ILD. Consider superimposed acute process (interstitial edema or diffuse atypical infection).

impression:

 Lung volumes were quite low on ___ and there was moderate atelectasis

impression:
1. Heart is normal in size.  Mediastinal contours are likely within normal
 limits.  There is some prominence of both hila which more likely reflect
 prominent pulmonary vasculature rather than lymphadenopathy. No evidence of
 pneumothorax. 
 
 2. There is a diffuse interstitial abnormality as well as a more patchy
 opacity in the retrocardiac region, a component of which is linear and may
 represent subsegmental atelectasis.  There is likely a small left effusion. 
 In the absence of comparison studies, this could reflect a chronic
 interstitial abnormality with a superimposed left lower lobe atelectasis,
 pneumonia or aspiration.  Alternatively, mild interstitial edema should also
 be considered. Clinical correlation is advised.
summarized: Normal heart/mediastinum; prominent vascular hila. No pneumothorax. Diffuse interstitial changes and LLL opacity; possible atelectasis. Small left effusion. DDx: pneumonia/aspiration vs edema.

impression:

impression:

 Differential diagnosis includes septic emboli, with or without endocarditis,
 and disseminated mycobacterial or fungal infection. It is also possible that
 these lesions may have preceded recent infectious symptoms, and therefore the
 differential diagnosis includes cavitated metastases; in a female patient of
 this age choriocarcinoma should be investigated.

 the extent of cavitation.

impression:

 recently ___:
